questions.text: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because of repeated episodes of daydreaming over the past 2 months. The mother reports that during these episodes, the boy abruptly stops what he is doing and just stares into space. She says that he sometimes also smacks his lips. The episodes typically last 1–2 minutes and occur 2–3 times per week. Initially, the boy only experienced the symptoms at school but last week he had an episode while playing baseball with his father. When his father tried to talk to him, he did not seem to listen. After the episode, he was confused for 10 minutes and too tired to play. The patient has been healthy except for an episode of otitis media 1 year ago that was treated with amoxicillin. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical and neurological examinations show no other abnormalities. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Defiant behavior towards figures of authority
Impairment in communication and social interaction
Temporal lobe spikes on ictal EEG
Slow spike-wave complexes on ictal EEG

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Defiant behavior towards figures of authority is a diagnostic criterion of oppositional defiant disorder. Since this boy has no history of openly defying his parents or being irritable, this diagnosis can be ruled out. His unresponsiveness towards his father can be attributed to a postictal state rather than deliberately ignoring being spoken to.

B) INCORRECT:

Difficulty sustaining attention is a diagnostic feature of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD). A child may repeatedly interrupt an activity, appear to be daydreaming, and not pay attention to instructions or when being spoken to directly. However, since consciousness is not impaired, the child's attention can easily be regained. The absence of hyperactivity and impulsivity in this boy further rule out ADHD.

C) INCORRECT:

Impairment in communication and social interaction is a core feature of autism spectrum disorder. While children with autism often prefer to be on their own and may ignore unwanted attempts at communication by other people, the episodes described in this case are indicative of impaired awareness. Since no other features of autism spectrum disorder are present (e.g., stereotyped behavior patterns, restricted interests), this diagnosis is unlikely. Autism spectrum disorder is associated with an increased occurrence of epilepsy and should be considered as a factor that potentially contributes to abnormal behavior in children.

D) CORRECT:

This child presents with a history of focal seizures with impaired awareness, which is a primary feature of temporal lobe epilepsy. Focal seizures originate in the temporal lobe and are caused by structural changes or damage to the brain (e.g., encephalitis, developmental disorders). Seizure activity is visible as temporal lobe spikes on EEG during a seizure episode; interictal EEG may be normal. This patient should undergo an MRI to determine potential underlying causes. Treatment consists of pharmacotherapy with lamotrigine or levetiracetam; surgery may be necessary for refractory disease. The prognosis is unfavorable, as only 40% of patients remain asymptomatic on pharmacotherapy.
Image Description:

EEG (10-20 system; longitudinal bipolar montage) of a patient with temporal lobe epilepsy

Tracings of the left cerebral hemisphere show anterior temporal spikes and sharp waves (examples in red boxes).

These findings indicate a possible epileptogenic source in the left anterior temporal lobe.

E) INCORRECT:

Although a child with conductive hearing loss (e.g., as a complication of otitis media) may appear to be inattentive or unresponsive when spoken to, symptoms of impaired hearing would be consistently present. While this boy has brief episodes in which he appears inattentive, he generally responds normally when spoken to and shows no abnormalities on physical exam. He also has no risk factors for developing conductive hearing loss, since his episode of otitis media 1 year ago was treated adequately with antibiotics and resolved completely.

F) INCORRECT:

While episodes of daydreaming may occur as part of normal development in children, daydreaming without pathological significance is often triggered by boredom, does not occur during physical activity, can be interrupted, and is not associated with retrograde amnesia or automatisms (e.g., lip-smacking). This boy's symptoms are consistent with focal seizures with impaired consciousness, which are often caused by structural or metabolic pathologies (e.g., hippocampal sclerosis, developmental and neurodegenerative disorders, CNS infections, head trauma). These conditions are also likely to manifest with impaired neurodevelopment. Furthermore, individuals with this patient's focal seizure disorder seldom remain asymptomatic despite medical treatment.

G) INCORRECT:

Generalized 3 Hz spike-and-slow-wave complexes on EEG are seen in children with childhood absence epilepsy. While absence seizures manifest with brief unresponsiveness and automatisms like lip-smacking, the episodes are typically shorter (5–10 seconds). Atypical absence seizures may last > 30 seconds, have a more gradual onset, and patients may be more responsive. However, like typical absence seizures, the episodes would occur several times a day and are not followed by a postictal phase.
Image Description:

Characteristic 3 Hz spikes and waves. The steep rise is the spike and the flat increase the wave. This complex usually occurs with a frequency of 3 per second (hence its name). This finding most commonly occurs during a seizure in absence epilepsy; it can also be seen in a seizure-free interval (interictal).
questions.hint: This patient presents with episodes of altered mental status that are associated with alimentary automatisms (lip smacking), occur several times a week during rest as well as during physical activity, and are followed by a postictal phase (confusion, tiredness). These episodes are most consistent with a diagnosis of focal seizures with impaired consciousness.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old boy presents for evaluation of possible seizure. His parents report that 15 minutes after he fell asleep, they heard a gurgling noise coming from his room. When they approached him at his bedside, they observed jerking movements of the right side of his face and profuse salivation. He appeared to be awake during the event but did not respond to his parents. He remembers what happened during the event and reports that he heard his parents talking but felt as though he could not get the words out to respond. The episode lasted for about one minute, and then he fell asleep. His parents report that a paternal uncle had a similar episode at age 10 but has not had any since then.
The patient’s neurologic examination is unremarkable.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Childhood epilepsy with centrotemporal spikes (benign rolandic epilepsy)

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy (JME) is a common generalized epilepsy syndrome that is characterized by sudden myoclonic jerks of the shoulders and arms shortly after awakening. In many patients, these myoclonic jerks precede generalized tonic-clonic seizures. Patients with JME may experience absence attacks, but they do not typically experience focal seizures involving the face, and the onset tends to be later than seen in this patient (12 to 18 years of age).

B) INCORRECT:

Childhood absence epilepsy (CAE) is characterized by typical absence seizures — transient impairments of consciousness (with abrupt onset and termination) that are often accompanied by one or more other features such as staring, behavioral arrest, eyelid fluttering, and hand or face automatisms. The syndrome typically occurs in school-age children but would not be expected to cause hemifacial spasms and dysarthria with preserved awareness as the presenting seizure.

C) CORRECT:

Childhood epilepsy with centrotemporal spikes (benign rolandic epilepsy) is the most common form of focal epilepsy in children. It is predominantly characterized by simple focal motor seizures that occur during sleep (as seen in this patient), although sensory phenomena may also occur. Onset typically occurs between 3 and 10 years of age without any preceding neurologic or cognitive abnormalities. The seizures usually involve one side of the face, the oropharyngeal muscles, and, to a lesser extent, the limbs (upper more than lower). Speech arrest often occurs related to severe dysarthria, and consciousness is typically preserved. Affected children may utter inarticulate sounds during the seizure but often report afterwards that they knew what they wanted to say. Electroencephalography typically reveals characteristic focal discharges in the lower rolandic (sylvian or centrotemporal) area, primarily during sleep, but with otherwise normal background activity.

Key learning point: The most common form of focal epilepsy, which manifests with focal seizures (usually involving the face, with dysarthria and preserved awareness), is childhood epilepsy with centrotemporal spikes (benign rolandic epilepsy).

D) INCORRECT:

Psychogenic nonepileptic seizure (PNES) is a diagnosis of exclusion that should be considered only after other syndromes have been investigated. Affected patients usually present with nonrhythmic movements, including pelvic thrusting and bilateral arm and leg shaking. These seizures rarely manifest with focal motor onset and do not occur during sleep.

E) INCORRECT:

Childhood occipital epilepsy has two forms. The late-onset form has prominent visual manifestations (such as elementary visual hallucinations, illusions, or amaurosis) followed by hemiclonic seizures while the patient is awake; the early-onset form (also called Panayiotopoulos syndrome) is characterized mainly by ictal vomiting, head and eye deviation, and, in some cases, prolonged unresponsiveness. Focal motor seizures do not occur with either form of this syndrome.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of episodes characterized by involuntary jerking of his right thumb that spreads to his entire right arm and then to the entire right side of the body. Each episode lasts for about 30 seconds and is followed by weakness in his right hand for a few minutes. Over the past 2 weeks, one of these episodes progressed to involve rhythmic jerking of all four extremities and loss of consciousness for approximately 2 minutes. He does not have headaches, visual changes, or a history of recent head trauma. Medical history is remarkable for poorly controlled hypertension and a stroke 5 years ago, which resulted in residual left-sided weakness. He smokes one pack of cigarettes daily and drinks alcohol occasionally. His medications include hydrochlorothiazide and lisinopril. His temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 76/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 145/108 mm Hg. There is a bruit on the left side of the neck. Neurological examination shows decreased muscle strength in the left upper and lower extremities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnostic evaluation?

choices.text: CT angiography of the head and neck

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

CT angiography (CTA) is used to evaluate for vascular abnormalities such as aneurysms, arteriovenous malformation, and acute stroke. While vascular lesions can cause seizures, CTA is not the initial test for new-onset focal seizures unless an acute cerebrovascular event is suspected. This patient’s symptoms and history are more consistent with a chronic structural lesion than an acute vascular abnormality.

B) INCORRECT:

Carotid duplex ultrasonography is used to assess extracranial carotid artery stenosis, which this patient likely has. However, this imaging modality cannot detect intracranial structural lesions that may be causing this patient's seizures. While carotid ultrasonography may be appropriate later to evaluate stroke risk, it is not indicated as part of the initial evaluation for seizures.

C) INCORRECT:

Continuous electroencephalography (EEG) is useful for detecting ongoing and subclinical seizure activity or for classifying seizure types after imaging. While EEG can localize epileptiform activity, it cannot reliably identify structural lesions such as tumors and post-stroke gliosis. In a patient with new focal seizures and risk factors for intracranial pathology, a different diagnostic modality is more appropriate.

D) CORRECT:

MRI of the brain is the best initial diagnostic modality for new-onset focal seizures. In adults, new-onset seizures are most commonly caused by an underlying structural brain abnormality. A history of stroke is a significant risk factor for focal motor seizures with a Jacksonian march pattern, especially in younger patients and/or when the stroke involves the cerebral cortex. MRI is highly sensitive for detecting structural lesions (e.g., tumors, cortical dysplasia, post-stroke gliosis). In adults with new focal seizures, imaging is prioritized over electroencephalography to rule out treatable structural causes.

E) INCORRECT:

Lumbar puncture (LP) is recommended for suspected CNS infection (e.g., meningitis, encephalitis) and in the diagnosis of subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH). A CNS infection typically manifests with fever, headache, altered mental status, or meningeal signs, while patients with SAH typically present with a thunderclap headache that rapidly progresses to nausea, vomiting, and cardiovascular dysfunction. Lumbar puncture is not indicated for new-onset focal seizures without evidence of infection or hemorrhage.
questions.hint: The sequential, progressive spread of motor seizure activity across contiguous body regions, typically beginning in one area (e.g., the fingers) and extending to adjacent regions, is consistent with a Jacksonian march.
